Comment: The story of this game: Black recovers from some opening mistakes, holding a difficult defensive position for a while. White tries a sacrifice to break black's defenses, and black manages to make the material advantage from the sacrifice count in his favor rather than white's.
This takes us a bit off the beaten path, but still with well-known popular responses for white. White will turn the move into an attack.

! Good positional exchange that will eventually lead to winning a pawn.
Another excellent attacking move. At first glance, it seems as though black's center is about to collapse.
Another excellent attacking move. At first glance, it seems as though black's center is about to collapse.

This decision to keep the king centralized has far-reaching strategic implications. It's safer than usual because the queens and 2 minor pieces have already been exchanged away. From here on out, exchanges benefit black, precisely because they make the centralized king more of a help and less of a problem.

The alternative is to lose the d pawn and any pretense of central control.
Targeting the doubled pawns makes perfect sense here.
This is black's only possible defense. The only other piece in a position to defend is the king, but that's tied down by the attack on d6.
Threatening Rd1 and a quick ending on d6. Black has to clear c8 without losing tempo.
Black has the tempo-gaining move set up. If the bishop goes to b3, black follows up with b4, removing the knight, then plays Bb7 to threaten white's center, and finally plays Nc8 to save the d6 pawn.
The best continuation available for both sides here appears to be 15. ... axb5 16. Nxb5 Kc6 (if not, 17. Rxd6  Ke8 18. Nc7#) 17. Rxd6  Kxb5.
Guarding a2 after the knight grabs the b5 pawn. This was not in fact correct play: white would have done better to press the attack.
Guarding a2 after the knight grabs the b5 pawn. This was not in fact correct play: white would have done better to press the attack.
The bishop is finally activated. The king cannot act as the defender of the b5 pawn without conceding d6.
Black's knight gets to where it needs to be just in time.

The f6 pawn cannot be defended. Ke6 is met by Nc7  and the loss of a rook.
